displayed_text: Family Member: And we … Doctor: And until last time your PSA was coming down. Today’s I don’t know Family Member: Okay. Doctor: if it’s back yet. But everything else, the hemoglobin got slightly better. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It went from ten point five to eleven point three. All of that, everything is improving in the right direction. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. The CAT scan also looks good. Okay. Family Member: Okay. That’s good. That’s pleasing isn’t it J___. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: We’re frustrated. Doctor: But he’s doing okay?

Family Member: Prostate. Patient: For prostate. (Chuckles) Doctor: So in the end you’re taking the blood pressure medicine and the Vitamin D. Patient: Correct. Doctor: That’s it. Patient: That’s it. Doctor: No other medicines for pain, anything else for the allergies – Patient: No. Doctor: Or vitamins? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. And when you were in the hospital, did they put any tubes or anything in, anything of that you still have. Patient: Yes, they put catheter in and uh they gave me I.V. at the beginning and made sure the catheter was out.

Patient: I don’t. Doctor: I think that you know it primed your immune system to help us for the rest of the way here. Uh it’s not something that we can measure, but it’s clearly um something that I’m glad you did. And it certainly didn’t cause the cancer to spread any more or anything like that. Patient: Well my quality of life is significantly better. Doctor: Good, good. How well are you controlling your urine right now? Patient: I’m good. I have a um. Family Member: He has a panty liner. Patient: I have a panty liner. Just like in case I sneeze, cough. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That’s I mean I’m full exercising. Doctor: Uh hum. That’s okay, good. So you’re not leaking when you exercise? Patient: No, no. no. Doctor: Oh good. Okay, so really going forward, there are sort of two approaches that folks take. The standard of care is that you um would get uh radiation to your pelvis, uh and most people, given the amount of disease you have down there, we also recommend that you get hormone therapy with the radiation. Um uh, so one standard of care would be radiation alone; the second standard of care would be radiation plus hormone therapy generally for two years, which sucks, quite frankly.

Patient: But it seemed like I, would have, I was degenerating pretty quickly for you know? For all the bone scans I’ve had… Doctor: Yeah. Yes. Patient: Somebody would have seen that somewhere. Doctor: No. I think it’s just crappy cancer not controlled. You know? Patient: And Uh. Yeah. Doctor: There’s, there’s the uh oh this is really going to be in trouble. We got that fixed. But it’s the bigger picture. Patient: You know uh you know and I feel I actually am you know doc I’m not running today but I’m getting around better. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: I’ve, I’ve seen the, you know the steady increase. Doctor: Yep. Patient: Uh, you know, little dips on certain days. Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: And I had to go in. Dr. F___ was over at the C___’s Hospital. I went in with Dr. S____. Doctor: You did not tell me she had a mini-stroke. Family Member: They put a PFO closure and found a hole in my heart. Doctor: Why didn’t you tell me? Oh, gosh. Family Member: Yeah. I have a closure piece in there. Doctor: You okay now? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: She looks great. Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Actually, you both, you both have come a long way. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: From our first days of meeting. Family Member: Oh, yeah, yes, yes. Right?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, that’s where we’re sort of in this legal stuff. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, it’s not that I think that (Zytiga) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? And, I can’t. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The PSA tells me it’s either this time or three months from now that we’re likely to see a change. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. But that’s what we’ve learned about Enzalutamide; don’t give up the ship until it’s clearly different. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Okay? Because these drugs could be providing a dampening effect
